comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Trying to work out exactly where this is . . . ?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Think I've got it, thanks to Google Earth, Google Maps etc - 

From the ridge of McMahons Point (Blues Point Road, Union Street?) looking south west towards Balmain in the distance,  Goat island in the middle,  Darling Harbour and the tip of Millers Point (with moored sailing ship) on the left.

Since there are no Federation buildings evident (nowadays they are all over that area), it must be c.1885.

Or not?

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: Its from north sydney.  Goat island in the middle,  balmain behind it,   the tip of millers point on the left.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I just found this John Nepomuk Degotardi (the father) panorama of Sydney dated "before 1865", taken from the exact position as this photo. The shrub and verandah have grown since (see note), as have several houses. This photo must be 5-10 years later, about 1875-80 and also by John Degotardi Snr ? acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=439957

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Good find! Maybe it's by a young Degotardi Jr. (born 1860), replicating his father's earlier panorama? In fact, maybe it's by the both of them?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [rewritten post - I was wrong, and mistook some of the buildings] The famous 1875 Holtermann / Bayliss photo (taken from a few metres to the right) show the houses with slightly less vegetation (see note) which implies this photo is slightly later than 1875, say c.1880. And probably by John Degotardi(s). The Holtermann Panorama + blurb - amazing - nga.gov.au/Exhibition/PICTUREPARADISE/pdf/Holtermann.pdf

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: There is also another panorama from a similar location by Francis W. Robinson, in 1876 - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=420921 . Frames 3 and 4 correspond with this photo.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Comparing with the Robinson panorama, I'd say yes. We just need the missing image in between the two.
